Which of the following statements made by the intern is NOT true regarding standard anthropometric measurements in pediatrics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Standing height is about 1.7 cm less than recumbent length.

 

Option D.

 

The statement regarding the standing height being approximately 1.7 cm less than the recumbent length is not true. In fact, the recumbent length (measured when a child is lying down) is usually slightly longer than the standing height due to the natural curvature of the spine and compression of intervertebral discs when in an upright position.

 

Standing height is about 0.7 cm less than recumbent length.

 

Option A, B and C are true regarding the anthropometric measurements.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Birth weight tripling by 1 year of age is a general growth milestone, indicating adequate nutrition and health during the infant's first year.

 

Option B. Skin fold thickness measurements at the subscapular region, along with other sites, are used to estimate body fat composition, which is crucial for assessing nutritional status.

 

Option C. Weighing infants and children to the nearest 100 grams is a standard practice in to ensure accurate monitoring of growth and early detection of any deviations from expected growth patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Length:

 

  • If a child is less than 2 years old, measure recumbent length.
  • If the child is aged 2 years or older and able to stand, measure standing height.
  • In general, standing height is about 0.7 cm less than recumbent length.

 

Points to Remember:

  • Birth weight of Indian children 2.8 Kg.
  • Term neonate regains lost birth weight by 7 to 10 days, preterm by 10 to 14 days
  • Birth weight doubles by 6 months, triples by 1 year, quadruples by 2 years and increases 5 times by 3 years.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by their mother, who is concerned about the child's noticeably shorter stature compared to peers. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the child's short stature appears disproportionate, with a more significant discrepancy between the upper and lower body segments. Considering a potential diagnosis of a condition affecting growth, the pediatrician decides to assess the child's body proportions more closely by measuring the upper segment and lower segment ratios. Understanding the normal progression of body proportions from childhood to adulthood is crucial in this assessment. At what age do the upper and lower segments of the body typically reach adult proportions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 10 years

 

Option D:

 

Upper segment lower segment ratio:

Upper segment — vertex to pubic symphysis

Lower segment — pubic symphysis to heel

 

Normal Values

Birth—1.7:1

3 years—1.3:1

7 years - 1:1

In adults the ratio is: 0.9:1

So, the best answer according to the options is D

 

Explanation:

 

Option A- By the age of 2 years the ratio is 1.4:1

 

Option C- By the age of 7 years the ratio is 1:1 whereas the adult ratio is 0.9:1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper-to-lower body segment ratio (U/L ratio) provides an assessment of truncal growth relative to limb growth. The lower-body segment is defined as the length from the top of the symphysis pubis to the floor, and the upper-body segment is the total height minus the lower-body segment.

The U/L ratio equals approximately 1.7 at birth, 1.3 at 3 year, and 1.0 after 7 year. Higher U/L ratios are characteristic of short-limb dwarfism, as occurs with Turner syndrome or bone disorders, whereas lower ratios suggest hypogonadism or Marfan syndrome.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51; Nelson 21st Ed Pg 1183

questions.text: A 32-year-old working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-month-old infant to your clinic for a routine pediatric visit. After returning to work postpartum, she expresses a desire to transition her baby from breast milk to cow's milk due to her busy schedule. She inquires about the nutritional differences between human milk and cow's milk, specifically asking which component is present in higher quantities in human milk compared to cow's milk. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactose

 

Option A:

 

Human milk contains higher levels of lactose compared to cow's milk. Lactose is not just a source of energy; it also aids in the absorption of essential minerals like calcium and magnesium and supports the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, which is crucial for the infant's developing immune system and digestive health.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Calcium: Cow's milk actually contains higher levels of calcium than human milk. However, the bioavailability of calcium in human milk is better, meaning infants can absorb it more efficiently.

 

Option C. Protein: Cow's milk contains a higher concentration of total protein than human milk. The protein composition in cow's milk is also different, which can be harder for infants to digest and may lead to an increased risk of allergic reactions.

 

Option D. Fat: While the total fat content may be similar in both human and cow's milk, the composition of fat in human milk is uniquely suited to the human infant's needs, including essential fatty acids crucial for brain development that are not present in cow's milk in the same ratios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Page No- 145.

choices.text: If an infant mostly has breastfed and less outside food, it is called as token breastfeeding.
If an infant mostly has other food with no breastfeeds, it is called as token breastfeeding.
If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.

questions.text: A pediatrician is discussing weaning with a group of parents. She introduces the concept of 'token breastfeeding’. Which of the following best describes token breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Token breastfeeding occurs when an infant primarily consumes foods other than breast milk but still engages in occasional breastfeeding sessions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Token breastfeeding is the practice where infants primarily eat complementary foods but continue to breastfeed on a non-nutritive basis, typically as a means of comfort or routine.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1795

questions.text: A pediatrician demonstrates a feeding technique to a mother who is unable to breastfeed due to a recent surgery. Which feeding method is being demonstrated in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supplementary suckling technique

 

Option A:

 

The image depicts a baby latching onto a device that allows for supplemental feeding while the baby suckles at the breast. This method is often used when direct breastfeeding is not possible or when additional supplementation is needed, allowing the baby to receive both breast milk and additional formula or expressed milk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Breastfeeding typically involves direct latching to the breast without the aid of devices; thus, it is not the correct answer.

 

Option D: Cup feeding is another alternative feeding method where a baby is fed using a small cup, which is not what is depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supplementary suckling technique helps to maintain the breastfeeding bond and stimulates milk production while ensuring the baby receives adequate nutrition.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 3789

questions.text: A mother with a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis is being counselled. She is concerned about the risk of transmitting the infection to her newborn through breastfeeding. The Pediatrician advises her on when it would be safe to resume breastfeeding after starting antitubercular therapy. For how many weeks should breastfeeding be avoided after initiating antitubercular therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Breastfeeding is generally contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis until they have been on antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period to minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant. The mother should avoid breastfeeding for the initial 2 weeks of treatment, as this is typically the period necessary for the mother to become non-infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommendations for breastfeeding in the context of maternal tuberculosis and antitubercular therapy. Mothers can often resume breastfeeding safely after the infectious period has passed, which is generally after the first 2 weeks of therapy.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796
